ID: A very German story has ended with the completion of the Humboldt Forum in a replica of Berlin’s former Royal Palace. The site - where the Kaiser once resided and the Palace of the Republic of Communist East Germany once stood - sparked controversy from the start.

Nobody knows how many child migrants pass through Serbia every year, in search of a new life in Europe. Many have been on the move for months or even years, and thousands go missing. DW's Fanny Facsar met some young migrants in Belgrade.

On this edition with Karin Helmstaedt: initiatives in Africa demand the return of looted cultural artifacts; a new building by Frank Gehry graces the Luma Arles culture campus; and the Verona Arena Opera Festival is back, thanks to hi-tech sets.
The Amazon - The challenge of communicating diversity. Study on the cases of Colombia, Ecuador and Peru.

Ethiopia’s federal gov’t announces a cease-fire in Tigray conflict+++South Africa's top court sentences former president Jacob Zuma to 15 months in jail+++Many injured in the Kingdom of Eswatini as protestors call for political reforms.

Pesticide manufacturer Hans-Dietrich Reckhaus is altering his products in order to spare insects. While he hasn’t completely changed his production, it’s a beginning. His first design saves fruit flies from certain death.
A cure for coronavirus is still not in sight. But as doctors learn more about COVID-19, they are beginning to adjust their treatment of patients — and look beyond vaccinations.

In a dramatic turn of events, Tigray's former leaders say they are now in control of the regional capital, Mekelle, and the Ethiopian central government has declared a unilateral cease-fire. Thousands have been killed since fighting broke out in November 2020, and more than 2 million people have been displaced.

Uganda is battling a resurgence of coronavirus infections, driven mostly by the delta variant. The government has tightened restrictions, closing schools, imposing a nighttime curfew and banning all nonessential travel. While hospitals grapple with oxygen shortages, the country continues to wait for desperately needed vaccines.

With the airline industry facing its biggest crisis ever, airlines and manufacturers are investing in sustainable options. Use of climate-neutral fuel is increasing, while Boeing plans to have its entire fleet flying on biofuel by 2030.

Every year around 1.3 billion tons of food are discarded - while over 820 million people around the world go hungry. An American company has developed a substance that can extend the shelf-life of fruit and vegetables.

We have the technology to transform seawater into freshwater. So why are we not using it to solve the global water crisis? Berlin start-up Boreal Light has come up with a low-cost and sustainable solution.

As the world moves towards green economies, sustainability has become a big marketing factor. But are companies that boast about their environmentally-friendly credentials as green as they claim to be?

Social media platforms are awash with pictures, videos, and all kinds of messages from youth all seeking ways to express themselves. But where is the limit? The recent case of a teenage girl from Cameroon whose nudes and sextapes swamped social media is one of many such examples. Are the young people who allow themselves to be filmed to blame? Listen to this interesting debate.
We ask our science correspondent Derrick Williams if there are any ways to mitigate your chances of developing a thrombosis if you’re vaccinated with AstraZeneca.

Celebrations to mark 100 years of Communist Party rule are underway in China. They'll culminate in gala events on July 1, the actual date of the anniversary. We look at the message the party is sending out. And Afghanistan's drug abuse problem. How continued instability in the country could undo one woman's efforts to save its victims.
The Canadian-American star architect's latest work is complete and a testament to his ability to create eyeball-cathing structures.

The Communist Party of China is about to turn 100, and it's pulling out all the stops to mark the occasion. The party has staged a gala performance at the famous National Stadium, also called the Bird's Nest, and preparations for a week of celebrations are underway in central Beijing.
A Tale of Two AstraZeneca Jabs - New Space Race
Data from space will be key to unlocking new technical innovations in the future. Navigation, communication, Earth observation — more satellites are delivering ever more data.

As more private firms and startups rush into the space sector and provide satellites for different missions, who can ensure that near-Earth space doesn't get overcrowded? Are there already too many satellites out there?

Pakistan, the "Land of the Pure" in Urdu, remains a paradox. Known as a bastion of radical Islam, the country is striving to become a modern state. This documentary examines the undercurrents threatening the stability of this nuclear-armed nation.

Every year, the German National Committee for Monument Protection awards prizes for successful and sustainable monument preservation. Our #DailyDrone presents the award winners. Today: the NABU local group Kirchberg e.V. for the area monument Hoher Forst. @Kulturerbe_DNK @NABU_de

The #DailyDrone takes you to the Schlachtensee student village. The listed section was built from 1959-1964. The buildings have been renovated since 2006, thanks to the Studentendorf Schlachtensee eG initiative — the recipient of the Historic Heritage Prize from @Kulturerbe_DNK.
Topping a Trillion - New Space Race

NATO and Ukraine have launched a major military exercise in the Black Sea and southern Ukraine. Sea Breeze 2021 comes amid a rise in tensions between the alliance and Moscow. The Russian Defense Ministry said it would monitor the drills closely.
Facebook tops $1 trillion in market value - Mobile World Congress begins without key players - Lebanon plunges deeper into economic crisis

The Delta coronavirus variant is spreading. Australia is battling outbreaks, along with South Africa & Bangladesh. Plus, the extreme heat wave in the US & Canadian West. It is shattering all-time high temperature records & endangering health.

Assisted reproduction is now only allowed for heterosexual couples. Some 3,000 single and gay French women travel abroad every year to have a baby. Now lawmakers are debating a bill which would make treatment available to every French would-be mother.
On Tuesday, England will host Germany at Wembley in the last 16 of Euro 2020. Historically, Germany have come out on top in these tournament clashes, with one exception that goes way back.
Lebanon plunges deeper into economic crisis - Mobile World Congress begins without key players - Young Africans earn a living from e-sports

There's growing concern about increasing numbers of migrants arriving on the island of Lampedusa, Italy. The island has long been a magnet for people hoping to apply for asylum in Europe – and recent weeks have seen hundreds of arrivals.

As the country battles a third wave of infections, President Ramaphosa says all gatherings will be banned for two weeks. DW visited the town of Kliprand, where residents were just getting their freedom back after two weeks of quarantine.

Italian prosecutor Nicola Gratteri is on a mission -- against the mafia. After ordering the arrest of nearly 350 members of the notorious 'Ndrangheta syndicate, along with politicians and officials accused of assisting them, he is now launching Italy’s biggest mafia trial in three decades.

While some countries' inoculation drives are in full swing, most are still struggling with a vaccine shortage. Governments should be employing extra measures to keep unvaccinated essential workers safe. Taiwan has come up with some innovative new rules to protect this very demographic.

Many Southeast Asian nations have been slow to inoculate their populations, especially when compared to Europe and the US. Vaccine skepticism is also playing a role. Hong Kong is now using prizes of real estate to lure people to get a jab.
We ask our science correspondent Derrick Williams if COVID-19 variants are likely to become more deadly and contagious over time.

We've become familiar with complex medical terminology and virological concepts since the pandemic began. But developments like the delta variant make it clear it will not end quickly. And we still have a lot to learn about the coronavirus.

Large parts of the United States and Canada are experiencing soaring hot temperatures. In a Canadian village in British Columbia, the mercury hit 46 degrees Celsius. In the US, the heat has forced schools and food markets to shut down.

German star chef Andree Köthe ventures off into nature every morning to collect ingredients. He takes what others would deem weeds and cooks them into delicacies at his restaurant, Essigbrätlein, in Nuremberg.

Vaccinating children is a hot topic in the current efforts to try to control the Coronavirus pandemic. DW interviews leading German pediatrician Jörg Dötsch on the ethics and efficacy of inoculating children.

Small solar panels are to be installed on the roofs of houses in the village of Sabana Real, Dominican Republic. The local project is part of a major plan: By 2025, the country hopes to generate a quarter of its energy from renewable sources.

Hundreds of dead bodies of people thought to have perished in the country's deadly second wave have surfaced during the seasonal flooding of the sacred river. The discovery has fuelled allegations that the government concealed the true death toll.
Mining cryptocurrencies is a power-hungry thing and bad for the environment. Does Siberia have a solution?

Politicians are holding an emergency meeting as new coronavirus cases emerge across the country. Several cities have imposed lockdowns and re-introduced compulsory mask-wearing. Experts say the current outbreak is the most serious since the beginning of the pandemic.
K-pop fans are rescuing Bangkok's tuk-tuk drivers who have almost completely gone out of business due to heavy restrictions on tourism.
As China-India relations remain tense over border disagreements, New Delhi is increasingly focusing on developing the Ladakh frontier region that has been neglected for years.
The American comedian with Jewish roots broke with a taboo in the 1960s with his parody on Adolf Hitler. That made him world famous and parodies became his trademark.

Spain has joined a handful of countries where terminally or seriously ill people can end their lives legally, provided they fulfill certain criteria and get doctors' approval. The reform came after years of campaigning by supporters. DW's Nicole Ris reports from Madrid.
MWC Comeback - Lebanon Crisis

The coronovirus crisis has forced many people the world over into working from home and has shown how important connectivity is. Mats Granryd of GSMA tells us what to expect of this year's World Mobile Congress.
Lebanon descends into an economic crisis that the World Bank says will likely rank among the worst of the last 150 years.
Berlin startup Sneakers Rescue repairs damaged sneakers. Now the young cobbler is launching his own sneaker. It's called First Fair.
Cathedrals, cloisters, churches, castles — the Romanesque Road runs through Saxony-Anhalt, linking 88 architectural works in 73 places. It is one of the most popular scenic tourist routes in Germany.

While evidence shows that children generally only suffer mild symptoms of the Coronavirus, most scientists believe immunizing children is crucial to achieving herd immunity. Finland is one of the few countries running trials on kids as young as six months. DW's Anna Saraste reports.
This week, 184 out of 186 votes on a UN General Assembly resolution condemned the 59-year-old US trade embargo against Cuba. Only Israel and the US itself continue to back the sanctions.

Russia is in the grips of a new wave of Coronavirus infections, with 90% of cases being attributed to the rapidly spreading Delta variant. In Moscow authorities recorded 144 deaths in 24 hours — the highest figure since the pandemic. DW's Juri Retscheto reports.

Thousands of migrant workers are fleeing Bangladesh's capital, Dhaka, ahead of a new tough coronavirus lockdown. Ships at a river terminal have been packed with people returning to rural areas before restrictions take effect.

Britain's health minister has resigned over a breach of coronavirus restrictions that he himself had implemented and emphatically enforced. Matt Hancock admitted breaking the rules after photos and a video emerged of him kissing and embracing an aide in his office.

Protesters have clashed with security forces in the West Bank city of Ramallah over the death of a prominent critic of the Palestinian Authority and President Mahmoud Abbas. There's been growing unrest since Nizar Banat died in police custody.
Escape from reality with Paul Bacon‘s fantasy cars. Electric feelings with the Toyota Proace. And can the Benz Victoria, the oldest car on Germany’s roads, pass the safety test again?

The Benz Victoria is 127 years old and still going strong. Like all cars, the oldest vehicle on Germany’s roads has to go for its roadworthiness test every 2 years. Will it pass this time? REV is right there where the action is.

Up to 6 people can fit into the Toyota Proace van… a fully electric version is now available with a range of up to 330 km. There are different driving modes for different passenger weight to help save juice.
According to United Nations estimates, almost 82.4 million people worldwide are fleeing wars, persecution, natural disasters and climate change. And it's the children who suffer the most.

There are 46 UNESCO World Heritage sites in Germany, many of which were built by modernist architects. These include Bauhaus constructions in Weimar, Dessau and Bernau, as well as the Berlin Modernism Housing Estates.

Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has apologized for "harmful government policies" and did not rule out a criminal probe after hundreds of unmarked graves were discovered at a former boarding school for Indigenous children in Saskatchewan province.

In Italy, thousands of Nigerian women are being forced into prostitution. The Nigerian mafia is suspected of being behind it. Insiders warn of the dangers of this 'new mafia' — with connections to Italian organized crime gangs.

Since 2006, D.Light has been offering off-grid solar power solutions — like panels and charging stations — around Africa. The products are relatively inexpensive, but why has the company been so successful?

Originally founded as an artist colony, UNESCO will decide whether Mathildenhöhe will be named as a world heritage site at the end of July, 2021. DW reporter Nicole Fröhlich visited the famous area in Darmstadt.

Bavarian Premier Markus Söder praised the "courageous acts" of citizens who tried to thwart the attacker in what witnesses describe as scenes of panic. Now residents are gathering to lay flowers and light candles for the victims at the scene of the bloodshed.

Hopes are fading that any more survivors will be found in the rubble of a collapsed apartment complex in Florida. As the search continues, reports are emerging that an engineer had warned three years ago that the building had shown evidence of "major structural damage."

More Italians are migrating to big cities, and every year around 200,000 leave to go abroad. Entire villages now stand empty. So small towns are providing incentives for incomers - like rent-free homes in Campania or one euro house prices in Sicily.

In Makoko, a major slum in Lagos, there are few prospects for the children — there's only one school. People here mostly make a living from fishing, but the younger generation could change that. Children want to be educated and transform their families' fortunes. DW's Fred Muvunyi reports from the school trying to keep their dreams afloat.

Anne Lacaton and Jean-Philippe Vassal don’t tear things down. They restore buildings sustainably with surprisingly modest means, while meeting the needs of residents. Their socially and ecologically conscious work won them the 2021 Pritzer Prize.

In 30 years’ time, far more people will live in cities than today. That means new cities need to be built. But what will the urban centers of the future look like? Utopian concepts for cities are emerging worldwide.

French President Emmanuel Macron announced the end to the country's military operation against Islamist forces in West Africa's Sahel region. He's said the operation would be replaced by a more international effort. Militants have been gaining ground in Mali.

Maybe by the year 2038, everything will be better! Humankind may have entered a new era of tranquility and overcome today’s global problems. Experts at the Venice Biennale’s German Pavilion explain how that's possible.

How can architecture respond to global crises such as migration, climate change, and political polarization? The Architecture Biennale in Venice is trying to provide solutions, by highlighting how we can live together more sustainably.

We humans are trashing our precious planet. We wage war, destroy the environment and bring the climate to the boiling point. Are there alternatives? Some possible solutions are on display at the Architecture Biennale in Venice.

Derek Chauvin has been sentenced to 22 1/2 years in prison after being found guilty of killing George Floyd, a 46-year-old Black man, in May 2020. In Minneapolis, the judge said he based his decision on Chauvin's abuse of his position and the cruelty he showed to his victim.

In Italy, thousands of Nigerian women are being forced into prostitution. The Nigerian mafia is thought to be behind it. Plus: The Russian student magazine 'Doxa' takes a critical stance despite government repression of the media.

Four writers and editors of the online student magazine 'Doxa' are currently under house arrest for criticizing the Russian government. But for the young journalists, accepting censorship is out of the question.

Science fiction combined with African mythology — that is the magical mix behind the aesthetics of Afrofuturism. Kenyan artists Osborne Macharia and Cyrus Kabiru, as well as Nigerian comic book artist Ayodeji Makinde, explore and celebrate African identity in film, art, comics — and offer a peek into an alternative African universe.

South Africa, the worst-hit country in the African continent, has entered a third COVID wave. New daily cases more than doubled over the past two weeks. In the province around Johannesburg, hospitals are already reaching their capacity.

The pandemic has had a devastating impact on the tourism sector in France. In Paris, the number of tourists plummeted from over 50m in 2019 to 17m last year. The French capital is hoping eased travel restriction will bring back some of the tourists.

Eighty years ago, Nazi Germany invaded the Soviet Union in a surprise attack, costing millions of lives. DW met a Russian woman who has been searching most of her life for the remains of soldiers missing in action during World War II.

80 years ago, Nazi Germany brutally attacked the Soviet Union. Even today many victims have not been found and identified. ++++ Summer vacation in the city or the countryside? Paris is finding it difficult to attract tourists.

Pakistan is registering and issuing biometric identity cards to 1.4 million refugees from Afghanistan living in the country. The UN refugee agency has supported this effort, hoping to better meet the needs of the refugees. But critics also see another reason why this initiative is being taken right now.

The Greek island of Lesbos is struggling with a tide of refugees. Dire conditions in the camps keep making negative headlines around the world. Evangelos Spanos wants to give refugees some hope — and is using soccer to do it.

Three people have been killed and others injured in a knife attack in the German city of Würzburg. Police shot and arrested the suspected perpetrator, a 24-year-old Somali man. Witnesses say pedestrians tried to hold off the attacker.

A world tour without crossing borders: some places in Germany resemble San Francisco, Tokyo and Iceland. Plus, the secret of the perfect baguette. And the Swiss Alps in fascinating infrared photographs.

Arabella Duffy, an inquisitive 9-year-old from London, loves history. She regularly transforms herself into historical figures and tells about their lives. Her short but highly informative videos delight her followers on the internet.

Zak van Biljon uses infrared photography to create his landscape photos. Trees and meadows appear in his images in brilliant, but altered, colors. He's out to reveal nature's beauty in an unaccustomed, modern way.

Soft inside and crispy outside is how the world knows the baguette, or French bread. The thin loafs of white bread are an essential part of French culture. What defines the original? What’s the best way to bake it?
In Scandinavia, a unique singing technique has evolved over the ages to summon cows back home from the fields in the evening: kulning. The centuries-old tradition is also kept alive in concerts.

A gushing geyser and a little version of the Golden Gate Bridge are two things that most people wouldn’t expect to find in Germany. Travel journalist Christoph Karrasch has collected them in a new book.
For the British carmaker Paul Bacon, reality is just too boring. He builds vehicles inspired by the fantasy world. Handmade fairy tale coaches and works of art you can drive.
Enjoy 'Koesister' - a deep-fried, syrupy-sweet specialty from Cape Town, South Africa.

A third Covid-19 wave hits Africa hard amid a shortage of vaccines, we visit a Kenyan hospital at the heart of the struggle.
As France ends its military mission against terrorists in West Africa, a new investigation alleges Paris is not open about civilian casualties.
The children in Lagos, Nigeria whose education could change their communities' fortunes.

German Economy Minister Peter Altmaier believes that the dispute about steel and aluminum tariffs can be sorted out quickly with the US. Simone Menne from AmCham Germany explains just how realistic such a view may be.

EU leaders have wrapped up a two-day summit in Brussels. The meeting was full of disagreement over how to advance communication between the bloc and Russia – and what to do about a new law in Hungary targeting the LGBTQ community.

The withdrawal leaves many Afghans who for years worked closely with US troops on the ground in limbo. Thousands of former contractors and interpreters now fear for their lives, as the Taliban is regaining control of several districts.

Jamaica is home to relaxed reggae beats and beautiful beaches. But the island has a dark side: young people especially lack jobs and opportunities and the murder rate is one of the world's highest. Many wonder if dancehall music plays a role.

Cooking show presenter Nazrudin Rahman from Kuala Lumpur is shocked at how much microplastic lurks in our environment — even in the food we eat. It's estimated that we consume 5 grams of microplastics a week, about as much as a credit card.

Jamaica's relaxed reggae beats are world-famous. But now, the dancehall genre has conquered the island, and it glorifies violence. Also on the show: the proliferation of microplastics - and how they end up in our food.

A ferocious third coronavirus wave is sweeping across Africa. More than a dozen nations are reporting increasing levels of infections. The rolling average for the number of cases has tripled since May.

What do our bodies need to stay fit and active? Is a balanced diet enough? Are there magic remedies? Well, for years the market for dietary supplements has been growing. But do we need pills to stay healthy?

Our human bones make us artists of movement and let us carry heavy loads. Everyone knows that. But they also perform other important tasks that may not be so obvious, everything from blood formation to protecting organs.

Some weight loss pills claim their products help people "lose weight at record speed." At first glance, the appetite suppressants may seem harmless, especially when advertised as purely herbal. But what's really in them?

Many people are looking to strengthen their immune systems during the pandemic. Some have argued that vitamin D can help fight off COVID-19, but studies don't back this up. And too much vitamin D can even be harmful.

Human beings are complex creatures. To be resilient and stay strong our bodies need vitamins and minerals. Among other things, they help our immune system and muscles stay in good shape throughout our lives.

Taliban militants have started moving into and claiming new territory ever since the US troop pullout began in May. Many of these areas encircle major cities, such as Ghazni, a location of strategic importance between the capital, Kabul, and Kandahar.

The Games are the highlight of every Olympic athlete's career. How are they dealing with the 2020 Games in Tokyo being postponed by a year? With so much in doubt, what effect has it had on their training schedules, their preparation and their lives?

Adriana Neligan from the German Economic Institute takes a look at what difference a supply chain law will make that was passed by the German upper house on Friday. Will it help the environment and reduce child labor?
Human fossils unearthed in Israel add new layers to our evolution. A look at the famous fossils that shed light on our ancestors and their creative pursuits.

Is it fair to say you've been outraged by some of the risky things you've seen people doing during this pandemic? And is it also fair to say that maybe (just maybe) your assessment of how risky those things were.... was very, very biased? Also, why are so many of us so anxious about life going back to normal?
A growing global campaign is approaching a landmark in the fight against climate change: holding individuals responsible for mass environmental harm.

On this Shift Special, German bitcoin expert Lina Seiche meets start-up founders in the Philippines. With the aid of blockchain technology, they aim to give people without bank accounts access to the financial system.
Former militiamen are returning to arms as Taliban forces gain ground in northern Afghanistan. The government has launched what it called National Mobilization and armed local volunteers.

New Icelandic airline Play has launched commercial flights on routes to Europe and North America, seeking advantages from available slots and cheap planes. CEO Birger Jonsson expects strong demand quick growth.

It's sparked celebrations, caused controversy, forced tears and lost elections. As Germany travel to Wembley to face England in the Euro 2020 round of 16 on Tuesday, we look back at some of the fixture's best moments.

New regulation requires German companies to prove their supply chains are free of human rights abuses. Critics say it's too much bureaucracy and disadvantages companies from here. Others see a benefits in it.

The African Union wants to vaccinate 60% of the continent's population by 2022. DW speaks with World Bank President David Malpass about how it aims to help AU to purchase and deploy vaccines for up to 400 million people.

Climate change is now causing soil erosion and parched fields in Germany. Maria Giménez is an artist who also manages a farm. She's turned to agroforestry, where trees are planted on farmland to help store water in the ground.

In 2004, Wangari Maathai became the first environmentalist to win the Nobel Peace Prize. The woman who launched the Green Belt Movement was convinced of the value of planting trees to conserve the environment and secure people's livelihoods.

People who buy products certified by the Forest Stewardship Council assume they are helping the environment. But FSC criteria also allow for the felling of old-growth forests. Conservation groups say customers are being misled.
This week's viewer question comes from Veronica Vellejo in Mexico: Why is loving yourself so important for well-being?

Breeding laboratory mice for research purposes benefits humans -- but also poses a moral dilemma. Are there alternatives? Also: the benefits of loving yourself, and the story of conservation heroine Wangari Maathai.

Rescue teams are searching for nearly 100 people still missing after part of a 12-storey apartment building near Miami, Florida, collapsed in the middle of the night. US President Joe Biden has declared a state of emergency in Florida and authorized federal assistance for the relief effort.

An alarming rise in COVID-19 cases driven by the spread of the delta variant in western Kenya is leading to a shortage of medical oxygen. DW's Mariel Müller visited a hospital in Kisumu County, where the shortage of oxygen and high-flow oxygen devices is making it difficult to save patients.

In Uganda, people living with HIV and the medical community point to prejudice as a major barrier to the well-being of those infected. Segregation of HIV-positive people is common because people are afraid of contracting the virus. Despite the country's progress in fighting HIV in Uganda, the challenges are still immense.

The battle for the rights of LGBTQI+ people began over half a century ago in New York City. A police raid on a gay bar, the Stonewall Inn, in June 1969, triggered days of rioting. A year later, the first Gay Pride parade made its way through the streets of Manhattan.

Following talks in Washington, German Economics Minister Peter Altmaier told DW he expected to resolve the US-German dispute over Nord Stream 2 by August. Altmaier described the Russian pipeline as "crucially important."

Britney Spears delivers shocking testimony about her life under court-appointed guradianship of her father for the last 13 years. Entertainment journalist KJ Mathews tells Brent Goff on The Day that it is "very hard to believe" that this would have happened to a big star like Britney if "she were not a woman".

Over the past 10 years, Laila Haidari has been fighting to help drug addicts in Afghanistan's capital Kabul ― without government or international funding. Now that international troops are departing, she fears for her freedoms.

For years, many Afghans worked closely with US troops on the ground. The US troop withdrawal now leaves them in limbo. Thousands of former contractors and interpreters now fear for their lives, with the Taliban regaining control of several districts.

EU leaders gathered in Brussels for a meeting overshadowed by a Hungarian law that critics call anti-LGBTQ. In addition, France and Germany are proposing a summit between the EU and Russia, inspired by the recent Biden/Putin meeting.

By combining art with daily life, the artists of Mathildenhöhe paved the way for modernism some 120 years ago. Join Check-in host Nicole Fröhlich on a tour of the stunning location that housed their former colony.

Belarusian opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya speaks to DW about how her husband, Belarusian video blogger Syarhey Tsikhanouski, is among six people facing a range of charges including inciting social hatred and organizing mass disorder.

On this week's Eco Africa, we discover how Andean animals improve soil in South Africa, learn how printing a 3D beehive can help the little pollinators survive and get our hands dirty with vertical farming.

An organic pear farm in South Africa uses alpacas to trim the grass and make fertilizer. The animals, which are usually found high in the Andes, may be a strange sight but they are proving their worth far from home.

Extreme E is a race for small electric-powered SUVs and it has come to Senegal. There it is showing off some of the most extreme regions in the world and bringing attention to drought, deforestation and emissions.
Should employers be allowed to sack people who refuse to get inoculated against the coronavirus? DW's Ben Fajzullin discusses this with two people who are holding contrarian views on the issue.
A startup in Berlin has come up with a new type of beehive that can protect the tiny pollinators inside from Varroa mites. The trick is creating a climate that the bees like, but the mites don't.

No, you're not alone. As the world re-opens, hundreds of millions of people are feeling completely overwhelmed at the idea of 'going back to the way things were before.' This feeling (which is absolutely normal) is called 'reentry anxiety.' And there are concrete things you can do to make it go away.
In Kenya, a group is training women and young people in vertical farming, since prolonged dry seasons and a lack of proper storage for produce are making traditional methods more difficult.

It's hard to make a living as a shepherd or farmer in the mountains of northeastern Albania. But an NGO is devoted to environmental protection and helping families find sustainable livelihoods to stop the young leaving.

German business confidence has hit its highest level since the end of 2018 as the economic recovery is gaining momentum. After exports, domestic business activity is rebounding, says Clemens Fuest from the ifo Institute.

High in the Andes mountains, mining companies are gearing up for the massive extraction of lithium -- the raw material of the future. Lithium batteries are used to power the electric vehicles that will play a key role in the new energy revolution.

In a remote and dry corner of Pakistan near the Indian border, a wildlife sanctuary has protected a complex ecosystem for migratory birds. This is where conservationists have made special efforts to save peafowl.

Indonesia’s lucrative tin mines have moved offshore, threatening the area's rich fishing grounds. Activists are trying to keep the mines from moving out to sea. But in a place where well-paid jobs are hard to find, the mines have their supporters.
Taiwan’s success in containing the virus and the insistence on developing domestic vaccine might have delayed its vaccine acquisition strategy.

Oil is big business. It's an industry that employs an estimated 6 million people from Russia to Saudi Arabia to the US. But oil is a leading contributor to climate change and can lead to leaks and spills that pollute waterways and ecosystems. As the world gets more serious about shifting away from fossil fuels, the future for oil looks tenuous.
The pro-democracy newspaper Apple Daily is closing down after constant harassment from authorities. The paper's closure is seen as the silencing of one of the last pro-democracy voices in Hong Kong.

The marine mammal got stranded at Lumley Beach in Sierra Leone's capital. Many people from around Freetown capital came to watch the stranded whale. A tractor eventually helped move the mid-sized humpback back into the sea.
Check out some of the top speakers that participated in the DW Global Media Forum 2021. We we honored to welcome these renowned voices from around the world to discuss "Disruption and Innovation".
An airstrike on a market in Ethiopia’s northern Tigray region has killed at least 50 people. There have been reports that medical teams were prevented from traveling to the scene.
We know that obesity can lead to severe COVID-19 complications, as can high blood pressure or diabetes. So is our diet our destiny?
The 'nicotine hypothesis' made headlines when a couple of studies suggested an active chemical in tobacco could help protect against Covid-19.

Water is fundamental to life. Despite this basic need, almost half of the world's population experience water shortages or drought. We look at ideas to use water sustainably.

Fresh, clean water from the tap is far from the norm in many countries. In India, many residents rely on water tanks for their daily needs. A company in Delhi is converting sewage water into drinking water. But barriers to acceptance are high.

City trees lower temperatures and improve air quality. But climate change poses a threat to them. A project at Berlin's CityLab has created a website showing residents which trees need water so they can help.

Around the world, approximately one million plastic bottles are bought every minute. Disposing of them is one of the biggest environmental challenges humans face. But has Germany found a sustainable solution?

Water tanks have historically been a way to deal with water shortages in parts of India's Tamil Nadu state. But rapid urbanization has destroyed some. An organization is working with residents to restore and maintain the ancient tanks.

More than 150 staff at a Texas hospital have either quit or been fired after refusing to get vaccinated against COVID-19.

Although protesting is serious business, a lighter side can also be found among the most arresting photographs of the past day. From Hong Kong to Afghanistan to the West Bank, have a look through the day in pictures.

Cyclones Idai, Chalane and Eloise caused severe damage to schools in Beira, destroying about 1,000 classrooms. The municipality is now using repurposed buses, or "machimbombos", as classrooms. Five of them are in a Beira elementary school.
After months of pandemic restrictions, Berlin's culture scene is back. Warm temperatures and a decline in Covid cases are making to possible.

The coronavirus has spread around the world. But international travel restrictions have not been lifted. Professor Dirk Brockmann, an epidemiologist at Berlin's Humboldt University, explains the effects of virus mutations on the pandemic.
Could this be the answer to housing shortages? A simple design built with simple, sustainable materials, to any size or shape? Wikkelhouse — it's the 3D printer of housing construction.
To mark the 60th anniversary of the German-Turkish recruitment agreement, the Ruhr Museum is exhibiting photographs by Istanbul photographer Ergun Cagatay.

Iowa's industrial agricultural system suffered massive damages after a storm tore through the area in August 2020. But between the vast monocultures of soy and ethanol corn, the Indigenous Meskwaki Nation grows food using different techniques that may provide key lessons for farmers wanting a more resilient and sustainable agricultural system in the face of increasingly severe climatic changes.

On a rock in the river that now marks the boundary between Serbia and Bosnia-Herzegovina is a house with a moving history. The Drina river house has been destroyed seven times due to the Yugoslav Wars and to flooding, but it's been rebuilt each time.

Thirty percent of France's bee population has died off due to climate change and pests. To make up for the losses, some beekeepers are stealing beehives from their colleagues. There have been 600 such cases in 2021 so far.

At the height of the pandemic, the Way of St. James was closed, and Santiago de Compostela was practically deserted. Now regional borders and hostels along the route have reopened, in time for what is called a Holy Year on the Camino de Santiago.

Charlie Mullins is the founder of Pimlico Plumbers, London's largest independent plumbing company. He says his employees will all have to get vaccinated. If they don't agree, they can't work there for safety reasons.
Germany’s Chancellor of almost 16 years, Angela Merkel, has given her last speech in parliament. DW looks back at some of her best moments in parliament.

For many around the world, cryptocurrencies are just something to trade and make money from. But in some dysfunctional economies, they provide a vital role for ordinary citizens looking to sidestep hyperinflation.
Five years after the Brexit referendum, many British companies now complain about higher transport costs and more bureaucracy. But the biggest problem is a labor shortage.

Five years ago Britain voted to leave the European Union. The Brexit referendum divided the country and continues to divide the nation today. Political commentator Jon Worth tells Brent Goff on The Day that 5 years ago he couldn't have imagined the "amount of political breakdown" Britain would have to go through to leave the EU.

After 26 years in operation, the "Apple Daily" has printed its last edition. Staff say the paper has been forced to close since China enacted a sweeping national security law, arresting journalists and pro-democracy activists.

Libya has been unstable since 2011, when an uprising toppled dictator Moammar Gadhafi. Leaders discussed the withdrawal of foreign fighters and upcoming elections in December. It's hoped the vote will finally bring some unity to the country.
The coronavirus is running rampant in the capital Kabul while security forces lose the battle with the Taliban. What happens when COVID-19 attacks a country at war?
We ask our science correspondent Derrick Williams what happens when you skip the second jab or if it is not on schedule. How long should we wait before receiving the second shot?

Sotheby's will accept cryptocurrency for first time as payment for a rare diamond. Traditional money still acceptable but successful buyer can also pay with Ether or Bitcoin

The German port city of Hamburg is home to a vibrant community of Afghan migrants. They're worried about what the end of the international mission in Afghanistan will mean for their country and for their relatives back home.

Najlaa Matto is a Yazidi. As a young woman living in Iraq, she was abducted and enslaved by IS fighters. After she was freed, Najlaa went back to her home village and met other former slaves who told her about the ordeals they’d suffered.

A European football championship during a pandemic was always going to be a delicate affair. Now, with EURO 2020 well underway, UEFA is pressuring host countries to flout restrictions and allow for a more carefree experience. But at what price?
From cars to coal, recycling to school strikes — just how environmentally friendly is Germany?

Construction work on India’s new parliament gained momentum as the city saw its worst times during the second wave. Critics find that the resources put into this ‘vanity project’ should have been used to battle the pandemic.
The Sangorian militiamen in Afghanistan’s Helmand province are sworn enemies of the Taliban - and they're putting up one of the few pockets of resistance against the Taliban.

The invisible danger of pollution kills around seven million people per year. It's especially bad in big cities like Jakarta for instance. Haiti has been in turmoil for years. Escalating gang violence has pushed thousands from their homes in the capital Port-au-Prince. And the pandemic has intensified the strain on humanitarian aid as funding dropped. Where do we go from here?
Nine out of 10 new infections. That's how dominant the delta variant is set to become in the EU within 10 weeks, says the ECDC. That has dramatic consequences for Europe's vaccine campaign.

Where is Africa's stolen art? In this week's episode, we are looking for Kenya's stolen Pokomo drum and discuss what should happen to Africa's famous Benin bronzes. Will they be returned and when? We are also discovering the aesthetics of Afrofuturism, checking out a youth-led creative hub in Nigeria, and explaining why mRNA vaccines are safe for you to use.

The sacred Ngadji drum of the Pokomo community in Kenya was taken by British colonial officers over 100 years ago and is today kept in storage in London’s British Museum. It is just one of the thousands of artifacts that are now kept in museums abroad. But no one knows the exact number of missing objects, or where they are today.

The Benin bronzes are the most well-known African artifacts, looted during colonial times from the Kingdom of Benin. Today they are scattered across museums in Europe and the US. The 77 Percent Street Debate is in Cologne, Germany to discuss what will happen to Africa's stolen art, especially now that Germany has said it will return the bronzes.

The Boko Haram insurgency has crippled northeastern Nigeria. But a youth-led creative hub and training center in Maiduguri uses modern technology, ideas exchange, and donor capital to unleash the potential of young Nigerian photographers and filmmakers.

Many people globally are worried that using one of the mRNA vaccines against COVID-19 could change peoples’ genetic material. That is wrong. We explain why mRNA vaccines are safe for you and your genes and will protect you from the virus.

Training courses for young female entrepreneurs are bringing about a transformation in commerce in Niger with the so-called women's fairs in Niamey. The events are attended by many customers, including foreigners. The fairs offer quality handicraft products and generate sales of about €15,000 over three days.

Data analysis by the NGO Development Initiatives shows that an additional 19 million people are in need of humanitarian aid as funding has dropped. DW speaks to Angus Urquhart, Development Initiatives' Crisis and Humanitarian Lead and co-author of this year's Global Humanitarian Assistance Report.

Escalating gang violence has pushed over 8,000 women and children from their homes in Haiti's capital Port-au-Prince in the past few weeks. That's according to UNICEF. Hundreds of families from impoverished communities had to flee to temporary shelters that are running out of water and food. This comes amid a fresh surge of coronavirus cases.

Around seven million deaths per year around the world are linked to air pollution. Over 90 percent of people live in areas where air quality exceeds WHO guideline limits. Particularly amid the pandemic, air pollution can be a deadly force as it further weakens our immune systems. One of the cities that's notorious for its traffic jams and bad air is Indonesia’s capital Jakarta.
Big Brexit Bash - Going Going Ghosn
Convicted mafia boss Sedat Peker has published a series of tell-all videos that have captivated Turkey - and turned him into an unlikely social media phenomenon.

As elections draw nearer in Germany, industry leaders are concerned about economic developments with the Green Party likely to have a bigger say. The Federation of German Industry hopes competitiveness will not suffer.
The EU wants to become more independent when it comes to lithium supplies. Lithium mines are now planned in Spain and Portugal, home to the bloc's largest reserves. But local resistance is growing.
As Libyan stability remains precarious, the two warring sides come to the table in Berlin.The aim is to force world leaders to promise to withdraw foreign fighters.

Five years ago, a historic referendum saw the UK make a decision to turn its back on the European Union as Leave campaigners hoped for more independence. DW looks at the economic consequences of the move.

As the Taliban positions itself to take provincial capitals before US troops withdraw, fears of historical levels of violence in Afghanistan grow.

The European vaccination campaign is making good progress, but German Chancellor Angela Merkel has raised concerns about the delta variant in the UK and lack of coordination on pandemic travel rules among EU member states.

US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's 1953 "Atoms for Peace" speech reframed the nuclear debate. His vision was to transform one of the world’s greatest destructive forces into a boon for everyone -- in the form of atomic power. But nuclear weapons continue to pose a very real danger.
Fed optimistic on inflation, but recovery is uneven – Bitcoin stumbles, China steps up regulation - Dubai sets sights on travel, tourism rebound
The Day's Brent Goff spoke to Jojo Mehta about her campaign to make environmental destruction a crime that can be tried at the International Criminal Court.

The Day's Brent Goff spoke to DW Sports journalist Felix Tamsut and Jon Holmes, who founded Sports Media LGBT Plus, about UEFA's decision not to illuminate the Allianz Arena with the rainbow flag and NFL player Carl Nassib's coming out.
Former Nissan boss and international fugitive Carlos Ghosn abruptly stopped an interview with DW's Conflict Zone, arguing "bad faith" by host Tim Sebastian.

The German Parliament's committee of inquiry into the Wirecard scandal has presented its final report looking into where Berlin and supervisory authorities failed to act on obvious wrongdoing by Wirecard executives.
Sotheby's will accept cryptocurrency as payment for a rare diamond. Traditional money is also still accepted.

Italy has been officially presented with its €200 billion pandemic recovery fund from the European Commission. The windfall comes just as the capital, Rome, reopens to tourists after a long hiatus due to the virus.
Bitcoin stumbles, China steps up regulation - German Parliament unveils Wirecard report

Eighty years ago, Nazi Germany invaded the Soviet Union in a surprise attack, costing millions of lives. DW met a Russian woman who has been searching most of her life for the remains of soldiers missing in action during World War II.

We ask our science correspondent Derrick Williams how long a vaccine recipient should wait before getting a third show of another vaccine.

Young people in The Gambia and Nigeria aren't showing up in large numbers to register to vote in presidential elections. And that development has left some people suggesting that voting should be made mandatory. Find out what the youth think in this week's edition of The 77 Percent.
COVID-19 has ripped through India, leaving horror and heartbreak in its wake. Officially, the virus has killed 400,000 Indians. DW looks at what is being done to prevent a third wave.

Less than five percent of Indonesians have been fully vaccinated - one of the lowest rates in the world. For Indonesians with a visa and enough money, a vaccine shot could be just a 20-hour plane ride away
In Cambodia, a passenger train has been converted to a site where people can take travel pictures and enjoy a coffee when pandemic restrictions are loosened.

Vienna’s Go2market stocks a currently exclusive range of smoothies for dogs. If they prove popular, they might be given a large-scale launch. A trial-product supermarket where market research is part of the retail experience.
Researchers have been studying our brains to ensure that we keep buying more products. It’s a concept called neuromarketing. Are we that easy to brainwash?

With barbers' shops closed during the pandemic, people took matters into their own hands –causing a huge surge in hair-clipper sales. It’s a similar story with computer equipment for people working from home.

Online retail has profited greatly from the pandemic. And social media sites have been quick to start another new trend – with their own virtual shops targeting one demographic in particular: Generation Z.

Marketing teams are always hungry for new ideas. Research on the human brain can give advertisers unique insights into what prompts us to buy. Meanwhile, social media has become a crucial sales platform. MADE on the latest consumerism trends.

Despite pregnant women being more likely to die from COVID-19, there is currently no nationwide recommendation to vaccinate them in Germany. But the state of Saxony has pushed ahead on its own. Now, many women are traveling there to get their shot.

The EU has started handing out checks under its pandemic recovery program, with Italy receiving the lion's share. Angelica Donati from Donati construction firm says the money may help Italy grow out of a long crisis.

Travel restrictions are in place all over the world, with one of the few exceptions being the state of Dubai. It promises tourists no quarantine and unrestricted movement, and visitors can even get vaccinated there.

Trade with Great Britain has been severely disrupted since the Brexit agreement came into force. Fish traders and clothing sellers are struggling to cope with new customs and health regulations. Companies often bear the burden of the extra costs.
Despite the rising numbers and low vaccination rates, South Africa still only has rather relaxed lockdown regulations in place.

Strict lockdowns meant that migrant workers in India’s cities lost their income overnight, forcing them to move back to their villages. Nearly a year on, many are still there.
Vaccination rollout was slow in the South American nation, but conservative President Ivan Duque blames his population. For weeks, thousands of people have protested against their government.

German regulators are confident they can prevent tech giants like Apple from engaging in anti-competitive behavior, says Andreas Mundt of Germany's Federal Cartel Office. But is it not too late to change the dynamic?

The Ethiopian economy was an African darling for much of the past 20 years, regularly reporting annual GDP growth rates of 10%. But the pandemic has combined with a conflict in Tigray to bring that to a grinding halt.

New Zealand weightlifter Laurel Hubbard will become the first transgender athlete to compete at an Olympics. Despite meeting all the qualifying criteria, the selection of the 43-year-old has still proved controversial.

About 10% of cases have resulted in long COVID-19, according to initial studies. People who experience the disease have become a new category of chronically ill people. But what treatments are available? A young woman with long COVID-19 tells her story.
We ask our science correspondent Derrick Williams whether travelers need to have been vaccinated with a jab approved in Europe to visit European countries.

The coronavirus pandemic has devastated the global travel and tourism industries. No sectors have suffered more. In Europe, revenues were down almost 50% in 2020. So many cities are eagerly trying to win back visitors.

Should there be a space for German war refugees? The Documentation Center for Displacement, Expulsion, Reconciliation is shining a light on a shunned chapter of history: the fate of the 14 million Germans forced to leave Eastern and Central Europe.

The pro-democracy publication Apple Daily is warning it may be forced to close, after police raided their newsroom and arrested senior executives. Government forces also froze the company's assets, leaving it nearly impossible to pay staff.

Beijing's apparatuses of intimidation deployed against divergent peoples and cultures generate a chorus of criticism. But long has Tibet been absent from such discourse, despite its admired legacy of resistance. The Xi Jinping-era is not only re-writing the history books in the territory. DW takes a closer look.
Many actors, especially women, have seen their boundaries violated while filming intimate scenes. One woman is working to make it easier for actors to establish their boundaries on film sets.
The Berlinale Summer Special celebrated the return of cinema in Berlin. Here are a few snapshots of the event.

For 30 years, the Hubble Space Telescope has been providing us with breathtaking images from distant corners of the universe. Now it's suffered a computer glitch. Here's a look back at some of its finest pictures.

Traffic controls, extensive bike paths and paved sidewalks aren’t exactly common in Brazil. The city of Belo Horizonte is setting a good example with its transport planning. A low speed limit zone and children’s play areas have transformed one area.

As the US and China are rushing to supply global markets with innovative AI solutions, Europe is lagging behind in commercializing its research. DW asks Nicole Büttner, CEO of Merantix Labs, what's holding Europe back.
The EU has stepped up sanctions against the Lukashenko regime in Minsk. Potash imports from there are now banned. Belarus is the world's biggest exporter of potash
Musician Felix Räuber has gone to his home state of Saxony on a musical expedition. Using recordings of nature, noises, and melodies, he aims to create a “symphony of cultures” with his music.

Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed's coalition is facing its first test at the polls after delays caused by COVID-19. But the pandemic isn't the only challenge he faces in the ballot box: Key issues include the bloodshed in Tigray, and widespread famine affecting hundreds of thousands.

The incumbent prime minister won more than 50% of the vote. A result that surprised many in the wake of the war with Azerbaijan, a disastrous setback for the country. Despite an emotionally charged campaign, only half of the eligible voters cast their ballot.
This week's viewer question comes from Sofiane El-Khalil Adim in Algeria: When could an asteroid hit Earth?
For more than 2,000 years, the methods used to conduct autopsies have barely changed. Now, a team of forensic scientists in Zurich have pioneered a new way of examining the dead: The virtual autopsy.

Benidorm is a popular destination for tourists from Britain. But although people who are vaccinated against COVID-19 and those who recovered from it can enter the country without restrictions, the British are not coming yet.

According to the United Nations, 82 million people had been displaced by wars and civil unrest at the end of 2020. Among them are stateless Rohingya Muslims in Bangladesh facing constant setbacks in returning to their homeland Myanmar.

Armenians head to the polls in a snap parliamentary election called after the defeat to Azerbaijan in a war over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region. Observers warn the conflict could easily flare up again. DW's Nick Connolly reports.

The season two finale is here! Guest host Marcel Nadeem Aburakia is joined by former Borussia Dortmund legend and Germany international Patrick Owomoyela to discuss identity in German football. Both Marcel and Patrick talk about what it was like growing up and playing football in Germany and how racism in German football has changed over the years.

A ruined wedding, an ugly scene in a coffee shop, a letter to a local newspaper. Listeners from all over the world have had a terrible time navigating our post-vaccinated world. Their stories get us closer to the actual problem.

Portugal is a beautiful country with a dark history. It's experienced brutal colonizers and dictators, and now poverty is widespread throughout the country. A new generation of authors isn't afraid to confront Portugal's past and the present problems.

After a pandemic-induced break in 2020, this year's event took place on a smaller scale as some COVID-19 restrictions remain in place. Tensions are high in the region after Poland and Hungary saw a backlash against LGBTQ activism.

Last year saw a dramatic rise in anti-Asian hate crimes and attacks in the United States. Police departments across the country have pledged to be more visible in the streets of predominantly Asian-American communities. Stefan Simons reports from LA.
In her novel "Weather", American author Jenny Offill shows that it's possible to tackle topics like climate crisis and online with humor.

Climate change, migration, and colonialism - the major topics of our time, in novels and nonfiction. Plus: A literary journey to Portugal, where a new generation of authors is confronting the country's dark history.

Taekwondo athlete Parisa Farshidi had been celebrating a silver medal win at the Asian games, when she was expelled from the Iranian national team. For wearing nail varnish. Kasra Mehdipournejad, once also a star in Iran, had similar experiences. Both finally left their homes and started new lives in Berlin. Sports Life brings you a story of two people in exile, for whom sports was a salvation.

Authorities in Portugal are worried about the growing numbers of the more infectious coronavirus delta variant. In an effort to slow the spread, traveling in and out of the capital has been banned for three days.

Nearly 300 people died in the Flight MH17 crash in 2014. Why did this happen? That's what a court in Holland is trying to figure out. Also: Marine biologists and fishermen want to preserve biodiversity and save the coral reefs off Kenya's coast.
All over the world, children are suffering from COVID-19 restrictions. Many kindergartens and schools are closed and children's education is suffering a setback. DW looks at one example in Turkey.

Prosecutors are calling witnesses and presenting evidence in the trial of four suspects accused of downing Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 in 2014, killing 298 people. DW spoke to a man who lost three family members and chairs a foundation that brings together victims' families.

In Kenya, coral reefs off the coast of Mombasa are dying at record rates, which is having a negative impact on fish populations. Researchers want to get fishermen aboard to help conserve endangered species. .

Heat waves are hitting the world’s cities harder and harder. Concrete-lined, narrow streets turn the urban jungle into a bake oven. This documentary visits those trying to cool cities down as global warming intensifies.

The Milky Way in time lapse. What’s the best way to photograph a starry night? Plus: soccer stadiums in Lego. Why is an English teen building all the German Bundesliga arenas in miniature? And: cooking over an open fire.
Chopping wood is part of the kitchen routine for this top chef in Sweden. Niklas Ekstedt cooks all his dishes over or in an open fire. At his restaurant in Stockholm, even the vegetables are smoked.

Photographer Kathrin Linkersdorff creates art from dead flowers. She treats the flora for months, then photographs them. She’s inspired by the Japanese concept of wabi-sabi, the acceptance of transience and imperfection.

The Salto del Pastor, or Shepherd’s Leap, is a custom still practiced today on the Canary Islands. It originated with shepherds using long wooden poles to cross ravines and steep slopes to keep up with their goats.

13-year-old Joe Bryant of Crawley, England, builds replicas of real-life soccer stadiums using interlocking bricks. He uses photos as his guide. Most of all, Joe’s inspired by the arenas of Germany’s Bundesliga clubs.
In his nocturnal photography workshop "Chasing Stars", award-winning Swiss photographer Markus Eichenberger shows people the best ways to capture the starry night on film.

Five years ago, 49 people died and 53 were wounded when an "Islamic State" sympathizer carried out a massacre at the Pulse LGBTQ club in Florida. Amanda Grau survived by hiding beneath dead bodies in a bathroom. How has she dealt with her experience?
Heligoland is a small archipelago that belongs to Germany 70 km out in the North Sea. The main island is made of unusual red sandstone. Lukas Stege went exploring.
Steve Hänisch explores the Cuban capital in a vintage car. Old Havana and its fortifications are a UNESCO world heritage site. An event visitors enjoy is the firing of the cannon at 9 p.m.
Viewer Yohanes Paulus Bisma from Singapore shows us kangaroos, dunes and turquoise waters in and around Sydney, New South Wales.
Every April, punks in leather jackets dance the pogo and swill beer for three days on the island of Düne. The festival is called Rock’n’Roll-Butterfahrt and attracts bands and fans from far and wide.
Düne is the smaller island in the archipelago and a nature reserve. It is home to the largest colony of gray seals in Germany.
Up to 3000 day trippers visit the island every day during the season. It may be small, but there is plenty to see - architecture, geology, flora, fauna, sea and sky, and Nazi-era ruins.

Ethiopians are set to cast ballots in a national election on July 21. It's a day of reckoning for Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed as he hopes to boost his legitimacy with the vote. The election is taking place against a backdrop of tensions.

The search is under way and seven ministers have been called to give evidence. But even though President Paul Biya has ordered an investigation, not everyone thinks that the process will bear fruit - as DW reporter Blaise Eyong reports from Douala.
Wall Street retreats on interest rate jitters - EU commission chief stresses need for job creation

The Nigerian mafia is spreading in Europe, especially in Italy. One of their specialties is human trafficking. DW correspondent Jan-Philipp Scholz visited some of the mafia's strongholds and spoke to a Nigerian woman forced into prostitution.

But overall turnout is expected to be exceptionally low. There is widespread apathy after hundreds of candidates were barred from running. Many voters are also angry over the impact of international sanctions, unemployment and hardline rule.

Forensic scientists traditionally conduct autopsies by making incisions. The 'VirtoScan' offers an alternative. Also on the show: What asteroids have to do with the demise of dinosaurs, and a German farmer uses sound to keep pests at bay.
East African Community mulls admitting DR Congo - Pandemic a setback for young workers

A flood of plastic waste has hit West Africa hard. Garbage from all over the world ends up on beaches in the Ghanaian capital, Accra. With the pandemic making things worse, the country now wants to become a pioneer in recycling plastic waste.

Thanks to smog and traffic, cycling in Tehran is as rare as it is challenging. The initiative "Green Club" wants to change that, bringing cycling to the fore by way of bread deliveries. Organizers hope it will help drive environmental awareness.

Zidan is five years old and suffers from asthma. It’s a consequence of the poor air quality in Indonesia’s capital, Jakarta. How can parents protect their children? The new DW series "Unseen" shines a light on environmental problems, and explores solutions.

The attack, code-named Operation Barbarossa began on June 22, 1941 and became the biggest and bloodiest front in World War II. In Berlin, German President Frank-Walter Steinmeier opened a special exhibition and paid tribute to millions of Soviet victims.
Jakarta is choking in smog. It makes many people in the Indonesian capital sick, especially children. In car-focused Brazil, a traffic project in Belo Horizonte is a pioneer of green city planning.
Up and coming British soccer player Kiyan Prince died in 2006 aged 15. For the computer game FIFA 21, a grown-up version returns to the pitch. His avatar plays for Queen Park Rangers.

William Shatner – famous for playing Captain Kirk in Star Trek – is having a hologram of himself created that will be able to interact with people after he dies. With the help of AI, the hologram will answer questions about the actor's life.
Can technology allow us to live forever? With the help of chatbots, holograms and avatars, our personalities can live on after we die. Digital immortality: this week's topic on Shift.

Industrial fishing is emptying our oceans and fishing methods also endangers other marine animals and entire ecosystems. Is it possible to eat fish with a good conscience? What should we know about fishing practices, aquaculture and certifications?
The Arctic coast in Norway is teeming with king crabs. These invaders are a welcome source of money for the local fishermen, but environmentalists and scientists are alarmed.

Making sure oceans are protected is vitally important because they make up 70% of our planet. They produce more than half of the world's oxygen, absorb CO2 and provide food. What can we do to preserve marine ecosystems?

The coastline in Ramanathapuram district has turned into a hotspot for sea cucumber poaching. This endangered species is a popular delicacy, but the sea cucumber plays an important role in nutrient recycling.

Native to North America, this turtle is a popular pet in India. Unfortunately, once owners grow tired of them they are often released into the wild and that is having a negative impact on local ecosystems.

Is it riskier to play a football game outside, or to meet one-on-one with a colleague inside? (Note: Your answer will say a lot more about your morality than you think.) Also, why is a professor of virology falsely claiming that spike proteins from vaccines are toxic?

Lockdown-weary office workers fleeing big cities in the Philippines are getting a warm welcome in deserted resort towns, where local economies have nosedived without tourism. As these digital nomads have found, sometimes all you need is a Wi-Fi connection and a dream.

The IMF estimates the global cost of the virus to be $28 trillion in lost output between 2020 and 2025. But besides the damage, there may be some changes for the better. Economists hope we can one day even benefit from the experience.
We ask our science correspondent Derrick Williams why Europe's medical regulator is apparently delaying authorization for the vaccines developed in Russia and China.
Sierra Leone's government cut a $55 million deal with China to finance the construction of a new harbor. The people living along the pristine beach fear losing their jobs and land.

Uprooted not once but twice: impoverished Venezuelans have been returning to their home country, fleeing political chaos and COVID-19 in Colombia, where they had sought refuge from an economic meltdown and food shortages at home. Urgently needed efforts to raise money for them have just kicked off.

An open flame, mold, or chemicals in furniture can irritate respiratory tracts, trigger allergies, or even cause cancer. And then there are allergies to house dust and peanuts. The latest topics at In Good Shape.

If Germany wants to meet its target of getting 10 million electric cars on the road by the end of the decade, the country's car industry needs to change gears fast. Faced with ever stricter EU regulation and CO2 limits, Volkswagen Group has announced plans to roll out 70% of the core brand in Europe as e-cars by 2030. But just how sustainable is their new e-car strategy?

France is gradually reopening to foreign tourists, and businesses in the French capital are also busy devising ways to attract them. But as DW's Lisa Louis found out, the city now has some unexpected competition.

Pakistan is registering and issuing biometric identity cards to 1.4 million refugees from Afghanistan living in the country. The UN refugee agency has supported this effort, hoping to better meet the needs of the refugees. But critics also see another reason why this initiative is being taken right now.

Germany serves as a hub for Vietnamese human trafficking in Western Europe. Nail salons have become an improbable front for a huge network that turns over enormous sums of money. Deutsche Welle joins the police on a raid in a small German town.
With reformist candidates barred from standing, Iran's presidential election will be won by a fundamentalist hard-liner — for the country's 83 million population a sad outlook.

Former President Laurent Gbagbo has returned home after being acquitted of charges of crimes against humanity. Rather than having a "moral character," the sanctions "must be maximally tough," she told DW correspondent Christian F. Trippe.

With a special solar-powered energy supply and environmentally friendly transport policies as examples, this major city on the edge of the Black Forest is considered to be a pioneer in ecological development.

Ivan Escobar from Paraguay went trekking and hitchhiking through Patagonia in 2020. He captured an impressive, often deserted landscape, all the way to the glaciers in the southern part of the continent.
Garon Piceli from southwestern Brazil presents the Iguazú waterfalls to Check-in viewers. This week's 'Meet a Local' takes us to Foz do Iguaçu!

Titisee has been regarded by world travelers as the epitome of the idyllic Black Forest since the 1960s. Travel restrictions mean that people from the region are able to discover and enjoy it for themselves.
Fairly old, fairly green, and mostly sunny. With the most hours of sunshine in Germany, Freiburg is one of its warmest cities, and last year it celebrated 900 years of city history.
Antimicrobial resistance is one of the greatest medical challenges of our time. Among the causes are industrial livestock farming, poor hygiene in hospitals, and the misuse of antibiotics.

Several thousand people in London, Canada, turned out for a march in support of the Muslim community, after a Canadian Muslim family was run over and killed by a man driving a pickup truck. The police described the attack as a hate crime.

Cambodia is deploying a fresh army of rats to sniff out landmines left over from the civil war that ended three decades ago. The new rat recruits are replacing recently retired ones that have helped clear hundred of mines across the country.

Manolo is a 65-year-old lawyer - and atheist - walking the road to Santiago de Compostela for the 99th time. For him, the pilgrimage is about contemplation and self-discovery. This time he also wants to test his strength after recovering from COVID.

The world's number-one-ranked football team get their Euro 2020 campaign underway on Saturday. Despite having had a squad packed with talent for years, Belgium are still looking to win their first major tournament. But injuries to key players have overshadowed their opening match against Russia.

The United Nations and aid groups are warning that 350,000 people in Ethiopia's war-torn Tigray region are suffering from famine. Millions more are in urgent need of food and assistance, UN agencies also say, but aid deliveries are difficult and dangerous.

Leaders of the world's seven wealthiest countries are meeting for the first time in two years for the G7 summit. They were welcomed to Cornwall by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, followed by a dinner reception with the British royal family.

Ninety artists from 34 countries, all with unique backgrounds – from different generations, regions, religions. Could it get any more diverse? The exhibition at Tempelhof Airport portrays the vibrancy of contemporary European art. We took a look!

What would Berlin be like without its clubs? Abandoned for the past year, these venues continue to fight for their survival. Marie Staggat photographed locked-down clubs. The images bear witness to the wild lives left behind.

Mies van der Rohe's Neue Nationalgalerie in Berlin represents a milestone in architectural history. The exhibition building is like poetry carved in steel and glass. Closed for renovations for years, it’s now reopening – and more beautiful than ever.

While Hollywood is cooking on the back burner, Berlin is booming. The capital is hosting a whole slew of new productions such as Matrix 4, Babylon Berlin, Spencer and John Wick. Films and series for the world – made in Berlin. Despite corona!

A league of her own, with a museum all to herself: After a long wait, Berlin can finally welcome Japan's superstar Yayoi Kusama. With polka dots and phalluses, she has been creating visionary art for 70 years. This could be the show of the year!

Berlin has been on winter hiatus for a year. But now it’s reemerging! An exhibition at Tempelhof Airport is exploring diversity, the Neue Nationalgalerie is freshly renovated and the film industry is booming. Culture defying corona. At long last!
Kristina Varaksina’s models reveal how diverse beauty can be. The Russian photographer transcends established ideals.

Lots of protein, vegetables and carbohydrates: that sums up what pro-soccer players eat to get them through championship matches. Former professional soccer player Hans Sarpei has published useful tips in a cookbook.
Debbie Lawson’s sculptures aren’t meant for the hearth. Her carpet installations are sought-after for exhibitions. She models polar bears, stags and kangaroos in wire and covers them in carpets.

Germany’s home to Europe’s largest safari park. Euromaxx reporter Diana Piñeros looked after the animals there for a time and met the ‘big five’: a lion, a leopard, a rhinoceros, an elephant and a buffalo.
Tarifa in southern Spain is a windsurfer’s paradise. German top surfer Nico Prien shows how to hover across the water on a hydrofoil surfboard. The wings lift the board far above the surface.

Germany officially acknowledges that it committed genocide during its colonial-era occupation of Namibia, and pledged €1.1 billion, to be spent on projects benefiting the Herero and Nama communities. But some are unhappy with the offer.

Russian President Vladimir Putin's government is cracking down on his opponents' allies by chasing them out of state-run enterprises. Trade unions say the wave of firings is politically motivated. DW met one subway worker sacked for signing a pro-Navalny petition.

Namibia: The former German colonial empire acknowledges the genocide of the Herero and Nama. But the reconciliation process falters. Also: A subway worker in Russia was sacked for signing a petition for Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny.
Tourists are heading back. It can’t be compared to May two years ago, but Europeans are gearing up for their post lockdown freedom to travel.

Hop onto your bike and ride along a pop-up cycle path. These new yellow-marked bike lanes have gotten things moving in Berlin. Hastily set up during the burgeoning coronavirus pandemic, to give cyclists more space and safety.

This week on Global 3000: Vaccine skeptics in the US relying on prayer to get through the pandemic. Releasing jaguars back into the wild in Argentina. Illegal gold miners in Mozambique and tasty street food in Brasilia.

In the Ibera Wetlands, marsh deer, tapirs and jaguars had been extinct since the 1970s. With a dedicated team behind a special conservation project, these animals are slowly being reintroduced to their natural habitat.

Many religious conservative groups in the US think little of COVID-19 vaccines. Although over 140 million Americans are now fully vaccinated, the vaccination campaign now has an uphill battle to convince the skeptics.

Brasilia’s bus station is a bustling place. It’s also a gourmand's paradise for those in a hurry. The culinary heart is the Pastelaria Vicosa. Here you can get traditional handmade pastries and sugar cane juice.
Twenty-one-year-old Catherine Nanziri will be the first female boxer to represent Uganda at the Olympics. But can she punch her way to the country's first boxing gold ever?

In Ghana, two Rastafarians sued a school after they were denied enrollment simply for wearing dreadlocks. Now a high court has ordered the school to admit them dreadlocks or no. DW's Isaac Kaledzi has met up with them in Ghana's capital, Accra.

In Rwanda, Human Rights organizations warn of increasing suppression of free speech. More than 20 bloggers and YouTubers have been detained or disappeared within the last year. DW met with one of the journalists caught in the government's crosshairs.
In India, an architect is mapping slums using satellite imagery. She's using it to create actual addresses for slum dwellers and make sure city officials know where to lay sewer lines.

Germany's Green Party are making their first bid for the country's top political post in September's general election. DW's Kate Brady looks back at how they transformed from a protest party to a party of government.

Where you find water, trees, minerals, you often find people. Some communities have more access — and this can be a boon and a curse. We meet the communities most impacted by our increasing hunger for natural resources.

We ask our science correspondent Derrick Williams if vaccines are causing a surge in COVID-19 variants.

The world is entering a new era of warfare, with cyber and autonomous weapons taking center stage. These technologies are making militaries faster, smarter, more efficient. But if unchecked, they threaten to destabilize the world.

Germany wants to ban child labor and forced labor from its supply chains. Companies feel, though, that one nation can't solve a global problem and that German firms will be at a disadvantage.
